title: Review: Russell Brand's Trew World Order is audacious, inspiring and funny
text:
British comedian, writer and activist Russell Brand joins the crowd at Rod Laver Arena on the first date of his 'Trew World Order' Australian tour. Photo: Meredith O'Shea 
Russell Brand's saucy take on Malcolm Turnbull and the Cayman Isands ​Full coverage - Comedy news and reviews COMEDY
RUSSELL BRAND'S TREW WORLD ORDER ★★★★
Rod Laver Arena, October 17

Russell Brand is one of the most entertaining live performers you will see. 
The 40-year-old is audacious, funny and inspiring, and possesses a wit that we celebrate in comedians like John Oliver, who paled in comparison on tour.
Advertisement Apart from a constant call to arms and talk of revolution, Brand's comedy is actually much like Oliver's: self-deprecating, satirical, highly political and anti-establishment.
Brand's audacity and overenthusiastic political activism can make him hard to bear, and his foray into politics with his famous YouTube show The Trews is oft-lampooned.
But in Australia for his Trew World Order tour, the long-haired Londoner jumps energetically around stage for a whopping 90 minutes and spends a large chunk of time making fun of himself.
That's the thing. Brand knows he's a joke, and he makes himself the punchline as he analyses everything from his embarrassing performance at the Oscars to the time he tried to join the Marines.
He laughs at Nick Kyrgios using girlfriend slurs to rattle his opponents, and taboo topics such as Adolf Hitler's childhood.
The best part about Brand, however, is the love that radiates from him.
He spends 20 minutes of the show mingling with the audience, hugging grown men wearing funny hats and riding in the lap of a woman in a wheelchair in the front row.
He constantly tells hecklers in the crowd he loves them and enthusiastically informs the 6000-strong crowd they can be part of a change.
While news organisations like Fox are telling us to fear immigration, says Brand, we should love our neighbours instead.
"Those people who want us to hate each other are just greedy little wankers," he says in his swashbuckling Englishaccent.
This is what makes him so great. While other comedians get on stage and bemoan the world's problems, Brand also presents a solution.
It is easily to be sceptical about this casanova, but in his presence, you're sucked in. 
"I hope I'm reaching out to the real you. The you when you're feeling alone at 3am because I am you," he says.
The effect Brand has on people is indisputable; when he finishes his set, dozens of people rush up to him, and he gleefully enters the scrum to high-five and hug every fan.
